Description: Tondo and foot sherd of Attic black-figured pottery stemless cup; interior: in tondo, black-figure decoration consisting of male figure (bearded head and shoulders remaining with tip of upright spear; added red on beard and tunic); exterior: around glazed stem, red band; foot glazed save for outer edge and stand surface.
Producer name: Ascribed to: The Painter of the Nicosia Olpe
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Beazley attributes the sherd to the Painter of the Nicosia Olpe.
Bibliographic references: Beazley 1971 / Paralipomena, Additions to Attic Black-Figure Vase-Painters and to Attic Red-Figure Vase-Painters (p. 196, no. 13)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 435, no. B701, pl. CCX)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1549) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
